pullRequest.title: Reference module: Identifying module types
pullRequest.bodyText:
Resolves: https://projects.engineering.redhat.com/browse/FCCEUD-40
@redhataccess/pantheon-developers Please review for technical completeness and accuracy.

nodes.bodyText: Use the attribute instead of Pantheon 2.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+[id='identifying-module-types_{context}']
+= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types
+:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE
+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.

nodes.bodyText: Passive voice. How about "For information on module types, see...
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@

+
+Module types are described in https://redhat-documentation.github.io/modular-docs/#writing-mod-docs[Types of modules in Red Hat documentation].

nodes.bodyText: Passive voice. How about "indicate the information/module type using..."

+[id='identifying-module-types_{context}']
+= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types

+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.

@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+[id='identifying-module-types_{context}']
+= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types
+:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE
+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.
+
+Module types are described in https://redhat-documentation.github.io/modular-docs/#writing-mod-docs[Types of modules in Red Hat documentation].
+
+Identification is done by using either one or both of the following:
+
+* The correct attribute after the module's title
+* The correct prefix in the module's name
+
+Use of the correct attribute (preferred method)::
+
+One of the following attributes should be entered in the line immediately following the module's title:
+
+* `:pantheon-module-type: CONCEPT`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: PROCEDURE`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+.Example
+
+`= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types :pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+
+Use of the correct prefix::

nodes.bodyText: "Module titles" sounds like the title of the topic, but I think this is talking about file names, right? I think that we only use info types in file names, but not in IDs.
nodes.diffHunk:

+:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE
+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.

+Identification is done by using either one or both of the following:

+One of the following attributes should be entered in the line immediately following the module's title:
+
+* `:pantheon-module-type: CONCEPT`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: PROCEDURE`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`

+====

+Module titles should start with the appropriate choice among the following

nodes.bodyText: use an attribute instead of Pantheon 2.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+[id='identifying-module-types_{context}']
+= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types
+:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE
+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.
+
+Module types are described in https://redhat-documentation.github.io/modular-docs/#writing-mod-docs[Types of modules in Red Hat documentation].
+
+Identification is done by using either one or both of the following:
+
+* The correct attribute after the module's title
+* The correct prefix in the module's name
+
+Use of the correct attribute (preferred method)::
+
+One of the following attributes should be entered in the line immediately following the module's title:
+
+* `:pantheon-module-type: CONCEPT`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: PROCEDURE`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+.Example
+
+`= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types :pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+
+Use of the correct prefix::
+
+Module titles should start with the appropriate choice among the following
+
+* `con_`
+* `proc_`
+* `ref_`
+
+====
+.Example
+
+`ref_identifying-module-types.adoc`
+
+====
+
+How Pantheon 2 checks identifiers::

nodes.bodyText:
Any value other than...
(Missing other)
I know what you mean by "defaults to", but I'm not sure that's the correct usage...would like to hear someone else's opinion. I would say "{product-name} uses the attribute"
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,46 @@
+[id='identifying-module-types_{context}']
+= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types
+:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE
+
+In Pantheon 2, each module must be identified by type: concept, procedure, or reference.
+
+Module types are described in https://redhat-documentation.github.io/modular-docs/#writing-mod-docs[Types of modules in Red Hat documentation].
+
+Identification is done by using either one or both of the following:
+
+* The correct attribute after the module's title
+* The correct prefix in the module's name
+
+Use of the correct attribute (preferred method)::
+
+One of the following attributes should be entered in the line immediately following the module's title:
+
+* `:pantheon-module-type: CONCEPT`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: PROCEDURE`
+* `:pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+.Example
+
+`= Identifying {ProductShortName} module types :pantheon-module-type: REFERENCE`
+
+====
+
+Use of the correct prefix::
+
+Module titles should start with the appropriate choice among the following
+
+* `con_`
+* `proc_`
+* `ref_`
+
+====
+.Example
+
+`ref_identifying-module-types.adoc`
+
+====
+
+How Pantheon 2 checks identifiers::
+
+Pantheon 2 first checks for the module's attribute. Any value than those specified is ignored. If there is no valid attribute, Pantheon 2 then checks the module's prefix. If both a valid attribute and prefix exist, Pantheon 2 defaults to the attribute.

commit.message: Merge branch 'master' of github.com:redhataccess/pantheon into FCCEUD40
Merge branch 'master' of github.com:redhataccess/pantheon into FCCEUD40
